CatDescriptText: William Rice, engineer, South Hills and Marian B. Ritchie, housewife, Coraopolis, were part of Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 13, 1960, pg. 1 with question: "What are the most appealing and least appealing aspects of the Democratic Presidential candidate, Senator John F. Kennedy?"  Mr. Rice's answer reads: "I like his youth, and he is a quite outstanding person.  However, I don't favor a Catholic for President."  Mrs. Ritchie's answer reads: "I don't find any least appealing aspects of Senator Kennedy.  And on the basis of religion, I don't think that he will be biased towards Negroes, but instead make certain that there is fair play."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of William Rice wearing dark suit jacket and light colored patterned tie with tie clip, standing near Mellon Bank, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Marian B. Ritchie wearing eyeglasses, and dress with compass, weather vane, and clock pattern, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
